lessons.title: Why Databases Exist
masteryOutcomes: Explain what a database is and what problems it solves
Distinguish databases from files and in-memory data
Identify data in real applications that belongs in a database

lessons.title: What Is a Relational Database
masteryOutcomes: Define relational databases as tables connected by relationships
Describe rows, columns, and tables using concrete examples
Explain why relationships matter for real-world data

lessons.title: üìö Theory Practice Lesson: Spot the Database in Everyday Apps
lessons.teachingInstructions:
Create a challenge-based lesson that is grounded in the material covered in the **current unit until this lesson, where the student demonstrates the knowledge they have learned in a fun and engaging way. Avoid coding in this lesson.
The lesson should include between eight and ten interactive and dynamic rounds between the student and the Maestro. 
The challenge may include different types of questions or learning experiences, such as varied question formats, interactive tasks, MCQ, identification or matching questions, etc.
You are free to choose any structure or format that best supports an engaging challenge experience.
During the challenge itself, there is no need to provide feedback or corrections, the focus should remain entirely on the challenge experience.
After all challenge rounds are completed, provide a short summary that offers encouraging feedback, highlights areas for professional improvement and refinement, and points out the student's strengths as demonstrated through their responses during the challenge.
Ensure the lesson remains aligned with the topics that were taught and is appropriate for the student's level. Don't code in this lesson.
Lesson goals: Identify where databases are needed in real-world scenarios and distinguish them from simple files or in-memory lists.

lessons.title: DBMS: The Software Behind the Data
masteryOutcomes: Define DBMS and distinguish it from a database

Explain at a high level how a DBMS stores data and executes queries

Explain the role of rows and columns in storing structured data
Identify when a table mixes multiple real-world concepts incorrectly

lessons.title: Hello, SQL!
masteryOutcomes: Define SQL and describe what kind of language it is (declarative)
Explain what is the role of SQL vs DMBS
Recognize SQL as the interface for querying relational databases
Get to know the basic syntax and structure of SQL using a simple SELECT query

lessons.title: More about SELECT
masteryOutcomes: Write basic queries that retrieve specific columns from a table
Get only specific columns and alias columns to improve readability

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Cafe menu explorer
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Practice writing simple SELECT queries to retrieve and alias specific columns from a single table in a relational database. Output: A query (or small set of queries) that lists menu items from a cafe with readable column names like ‚ÄúItem Name‚Äù and ‚ÄúPrice (USD)‚Äù.

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Bookstore inventory view

This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.

lessons.teachingInstructions:
Create a challenge-based lesson that is grounded in the material covered in the **current unit until this lesson, where the student demonstrates the knowledge they have learned in a fun and engaging way. Avoid coding in this lesson.
The lesson should include between eight and ten interactive and dynamic rounds between the student and the Maestro. 
The challenge may include different types of questions or learning experiences, such as varied question formats, interactive tasks, MCQ, identification or matching questions, etc.
You are free to choose any structure or format that best supports an engaging challenge experience.
During the challenge itself, there is no need to provide feedback or corrections, the focus should remain entirely on the challenge experience.
After all challenge rounds are completed, provide a short summary that offers encouraging feedback, highlights areas for professional improvement and refinement, and points out the student's strengths as demonstrated through their responses during the challenge.
Ensure the lesson remains aligned with the topics that were taught and is appropriate for the student's level. Don't code in this lesson.
Lesson goals: Deepen your recognition of SQLite as a fully relational database by identifying relational features in descriptions and distinguishing it from non-relational storage options.

lessons.title: Creating Tables
masteryOutcomes: Create tables using a graphical database tool
Define columns with appropriate data types
Set primary keys and foreign keys using the UI

lessons.title: Designing a Database from a Story
masteryOutcomes: Translate a real-world description into relational tables
Choose appropriate columns and primary keys
Implement the schema using a graphical tool

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Cafe orders database
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Design and create a small relational schema (tables, columns, primary/foreign keys) for a cafe ordering system using a graphical database tool. Output: A working database with linked tables for customers, menu items, and orders that can be visually inspected in the UI.

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Library system from story
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Translate a short narrative about a neighborhood library into a set of relational tables with appropriate keys, then implement them in a graphical tool. Output: A complete library database schema (books, members, loans, etc.) created and visible in the database UI with all relationships defined.

lessons.title: Inserting and Editing Data
masteryOutcomes: Insert rows into tables using the UI
Respect foreign key relationships when adding data
Explain common data-entry errors caused by schema constraints

lessons.title: Querying Data (UI + SQL)
masteryOutcomes: Run basic SELECT queries using the built-in query editor
Inspect query results in a tabular interface
Relate query output to the underlying tables and relationships

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Cafe orders data entry
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Insert and edit rows in an existing cafe database while respecting foreign key constraints and resolving common data-entry errors. Output: A populated cafe database with realistic sample customers, menu items, and orders correctly linked.

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: Movie rentals queries
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.

Exercise goals and desired output: Run basic SELECT queries (via UI and SQL editor) on a movie rental database to answer concrete questions about customers, movies, and rentals. Output: A set of saved or documented queries and their tabular results that show specific subsets of the movie rental data.

lessons.title: SQLite in the Database Landscape
masteryOutcomes: Summarize SQLite‚Äôs role among relational DBMSs
Contrast UI-based database interaction with writing raw SQL
Explain why relational databases are often the default choice

lessons.title: Beyond Relational: The NoSQL Landscape
masteryOutcomes: Define NoSQL as a family of non-relational databases
Distinguish relational databases from NoSQL at a high level
Identify major NoSQL types: document, key-value, wide-column, graph
Recognize which NoSQL types are covered in this course

lessons.title: JSON: The Shape of Modern Data
masteryOutcomes: Define JSON and its core structures, building on knowledge from Python‚Äôs dicts
Read JSON and explain the data it represents
Relate JSON to Python dictionaries and lists

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: User profile JSON explorer
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.
Review the student's work by pointing out what's correct and what needs improvement, then suggest the next step.
Exercise theme is to be chosen based on the lesson title.
Exercise goals and desired output: Read and interpret JSON documents representing user profiles, mapping them to equivalent Python dicts and lists on paper or in a REPL. Output: Annotated JSON samples and corresponding Python-like structures that clearly show keys, values, and nesting.

lessons.title: ‚öô Practice Lesson: To-do list JSON API mock
lessons.teachingInstructions:
This is a coding challenge lesson. In this lesson, do not introduce new topics; it is about solving an exercise using previously learned concepts only.
Guide the student step by step toward the solution without writing the full answer or final code for them.
Break the problem into small, manageable steps and ask the student to implement each step before moving on.
When the student is stuck, give progressive hints instead of solutions.
You may provide example inputs/outputs, edge cases, and clarification to help the student reason about correctness.

Exercise goals and desired output: Work with a small set of JSON responses for a to-do list service, extracting and reorganizing the data conceptually as if building a simple client. Output: A set of transformed JSON snippets (or outlined transformations) that group tasks by user, status, or due date using JSON‚Äôs nesting capabilities.
